Lifted limit on the number of visitors a long-term care resident is permitted to have at 1 time; increased the number of designated Partners in Care from 1 to 3 and lifted requirement for them to visit during visiting hours; permitted residents to have overnight visits with Partners in Care

Mandated the wearing of non-medical masks or face coverings in all indoor public spaces except while eating and drinking, during exercise or when masks cannot be worn—exemptions for children under 2, children under 5 refusing to wear a mask, individuals who are unable to remove a mask without assistance and those with valid medical reasons

Temporary suspension of participating in the Atlantic travel bubble for non-essential travel; individuals should travel outside for essential purposes or work only until December 8, 2020 (temporary suspension of participation was later extended by an additional 2 weeks until December 20, 2020—see secondary source; announced suspension continuation until at least January 25, 2021—see secondary source)

intervention.who: Department of Education and Lifelong Learning
intervention.what: Updated mask policy to mandate mask wearing for all staff and students in grades 10 to 12 at all times indoors, except during physical distancing, eating or drinking, physical activity, engaging in an activity that prevents mask-wearing, poses a safety concern or is not in the best interest of the student; all visitors are required to wear masks at all times indoors; effective for 2 weeks minimum

intervention.type: Public information — phase and alert level changes
intervention.who: Government of Prince Edward Island, Chief Public Health Officer
intervention.what: Province moved into an enhanced caution (yellow) phase

intervention.who: Department of Education and Lifelong Learning
intervention.what: Transitioned high schools in the capital region (Charlottetown) to remote learning for 2 weeks
Prohibited visitors at Health PEI hospitals, long-term care or any other facility, with the exception of compassionate circumstances
Received first shipment of 1,950 doses of Pfizer vaccine

Prioritized initial doses for health care workers and nursing home staff who provide direct patient care; this includes respiratory therapists, testing clinic staff, immunization staff, cough and fever clinic staff, emergency room staff and long-term care staff
Entered Phase 1 of COVID-19 vaccination plan and administered first COVID-19 vaccines to health care workers
Released COVID-19 immunization program with 3 phases aligning with the National Advisory Committee on Immunization guidance

intervention.type: Public information — phase and alert level changes
intervention.what: All regions moved out of the "circuit breaker" enhanced caution level and into a regular caution (yellow) level
Prohibited all personal gatherings except for 2 persons outside a household; limited organized indoor and outdoor gatherings, including weddings and funerals, to 10 people
Closed fitness facilities, museums, libraries, bingo halls and casinos; prohibited organized recreational activities

Closed restaurants, with exceptions for takeout and delivery; limited personal services to appointments only provided that masks are worn by staff and patrons at all times; reduced capacity in retail and markets to 50%

Permitted indoor and outdoor personal gatherings of household plus up to 10 people, with distancing where possible; increased the limit on indoor and outdoor organized gatherings (including weddings and funerals) to 50 people

Permitted gyms, fitness facilities, museums and libraries to operate at a 50% capacity with modifications for high-intensity activity; organized recreational and team sports may resume to the gathering limits, but tournaments are not permitted

Permitted retail stores, markets and craft fairs to operate at 50% capcity; permitted restaurants and liscensed premises to reopen in-room dining with a closing time of 11 p.m.; permitted personal services to continue to operate on an appointment basis provided that masks are worn by staff and patrons at all times

Permitted patients of hospitals and other health facilities and long-term care residents to have up to 2 partners in care with limited number of visitors allowed in designated areas; scheduled and timed visits in long-term care; in hospitals, no restrictions on visitation times and no requirement to designate visitors, with a maximum of 3 at once

intervention.who: Government of Prince Edward Island, Chief Public Health Officer
intervention.what: Permitted organized gatherings, including concerts, worship services, movie theatres, organized recreational and team sports, and restaurants and licensed premises to continue to operate with a total of 50 people; can have up to 2 additional groups of 50 people with an approved operational plan

intervention.who: Government of Prince Edward Island, Chief Public Health Officer
intervention.what: Permitted in-province tournaments for organized recreational and team sports, provided that the number of people in the span of the day does not exceed 50; permitted prior approval for sporting events that exceed 50 people
Temporary suspension of participating in the Atlantic travel bubble for non-essential travel, requiring 14 days self-isolation or application for work-isolation upon returning to P.E.I.

intervention.who: Government of Prince Edward Island, Chief Public Health Officer
intervention.what: Implemented "circuit breaker" measures to aggressively curb and contain spread, which are implemented as an enhanced caution (yellow) phase of the alert level system

intervention.who: Department of Education and Lifelong Learning
intervention.what: Winter breaks in P.E.I. regions follow the same schedule

intervention.who: Government of Prince Edward Island, Executive Council
intervention.what: Extended the public health state of emergency

intervention.who: Government of Prince Edward Island, Executive Council
intervention.what: Extended the public health state of emergency
Web page tracks vaccination progress to date
Announced expected arrival of 1,200 doses of Moderna vaccine in the week of December 28

intervention.who: Minister of health and social services
intervention.what: Granted a temporary bonus between 4% and 8% for employees who are holders of ambulance service permits, or who worked in health communication centres or the Corporation d’urgences-sante
Announced closures of all stores on Sundays in order to slow the spread of COVID-19, with the exception of petrol stations, convenience stores, pharmacies and takeout orders and restaurant deliveries
New roadside checks to limit travel from 1 region to another have been added by the Sureté du Québec, particularly in the north of Lanaudière, the Laurentians, the Mauricie and the Outaouais.

intervention.type: Public information — launch of web page/resource
intervention.what: Launched a new advertising campaign called Vedettes en chœur, in which Quebec public figures have agreed to participate from their homes in an awareness campaign to emphasize the importance of respecting health measures
Non-essential people and businesses who do not comply with public health guidelines will be fined $1,000 to $6,000.

Announced funding of $287 million for bonuses and personal protective equipment for health care workers who are in direct contact with patients with COVID-19, including patient attendants in private seniors’ residences

intervention.who: Minister of health and social services
intervention.what: Announced salary bonuses ranging from 4% to 8% for health care workers who are in direct contact with patients with COVID-19, including patient attendants in private seniors’ residences
Added new police checkpoints to restrict movement in 2 territories: the Charlevoix region and the city of Rouyn-Noranda
Released projections for cases and critical care capacity
Reminded the Quebec public that no physical gatherings should take place during Easter, regardless of religion
Announced that 450 doctors and 500 nurses are to be transferred from the hospital sector to long-term care homes and seniors’ homes

Announced that a team specializing in the care of the elderly will be in close contact with stakeholders to support them in the implementation of good practices and screening as well as in the organization of work in long-term care homes and in other living environments
Appealed to 1,200 long-term care workers who are infected or afraid of infection to return to work, and requested that people with expertise in care (e.g., nursing teachers) volunteer

intervention.type: Public information — launch of web page/resource
intervention.what: Announced that the government will publish the list of long-term care homes and other living environments under active surveillance by the ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux and the public health teams

intervention.who: Minister of health and social services
intervention.what: Extended the public health state of emergency

intervention.who: Minister of health and social services
intervention.what: Issued an order that provides students registered in a health care profession program (e.g., nursing, medical radiation technology, social work) with temporary permits on the condition that the student does not have more than 1 full-time session remaining to complete the program

intervention.who: Office of the Minister of health and social services
intervention.what: Announced measures to promote rapid recruitment of workers into the health and social services network (e.g., asking the directorates general of school boards, CEGEPs and universities to contact their health and social services students so that they can support the health network)

intervention.who: Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux
intervention.what: Published case definition (earliest publication date tracked using the Internet Archive)
Spring breaks in Que. may vary by region. English Montreal School Board example provided.
Travellers returning to Que. from outside Canada are asked to self-isolate for 14 days.

intervention.type: Public information — launch of web page/resource
intervention.what: Launched a phone line to answer questions about COVID-19 for the public and media representatives

intervention.who: Minister of health and social services
intervention.what: Declared a public health state of emergency

intervention.who: Minister of health and social services
intervention.what: Closure of educational institutions (elementary and secondary schools, training centres, private schools)

intervention.who: Minister of health and social services
intervention.what: Closure of CEGEPs and universities

intervention.who: Minister of health and social services
intervention.what: Prohibited gatherings of more than 250 people

Announced that Régie de l’assurance maladie du Québec will cover the cost of health services provided by telecommunications means (e.g., consultations by telephone); physicians to bill existing services when delivering by telephone or video conference; COVID-19 fee codes are available
Reiterated that people aged 70 and over should stay at home as much as possible, except in exceptional situations such as important medical appointments.
Prohibited non-essential visits to hospitals.
Prohibited non-essential visits to residential and long-term care centres and private seniors’ residences.

intervention.who: Minister of health and social services
intervention.what: Announced suspension of activities at places to which the public has admittance for cultural, educational, sports, recreation or entertainment purposes, including spas, saunas, swimming pools, amusement parks and water parks, ski stations, ice rinks, fitness centres, sports centres, movie theatres, arcades, dance halls, zoos and aquariums

intervention.who: Minister of health and social services
intervention.what: Announced suspension of all activities at all bars, discotheques, restaurants offering buffet service and sugar shacks; however, restaurants that do not offer buffet services are authorized to continue to operate, provided they admit no more than one-half of the number of clients they can normally admit and provided they apply measures to distance clients from one another; they may also continue activities of the “drive-through” and “takeout” type.

intervention.who: Minister of health and social services
intervention.what: Authorized professional orders in the health care field to issue a special authorization during a public health emergency to a person who has not been a member of the order for 5 years or less and is aged under 70, allowing that person to practise an exclusive profession or use a title reserved for the members of the order and to perform the same activities as those members

intervention.who: Minister of health and social services
intervention.what: Closure of licensed child care centres with the exception of daycare services (from birth to age 5) and emergency school daycare services for children (aged 4 to 13) of health care, social services and essential services personnel, with subsequent extensions (see secondary source column)

intervention.who: Ordre des dentistes du Québec, Ordre des hygiénistes dentaires du Québec
intervention.what: Issued a directive to dentists and dental hygienists to postpone all non-essential/non-emergency treatment and services.
Closed all outdoor centres, places of worship (with religious gatherings suspended, unless they are necessary), tasting counters and kiosks in grocery stores or big box stores
Encouraged employers to be flexible, where possible, to let their employees telecommute from home
Issued recommendations to chiropractors to postpone all non-emergency or non-essential chiropractic appointments.
Requested that optometrists postpone all non-urgent appointments

intervention.who: Ordre des pharmaciens du Québec, Collège des médecins
intervention.what: Issued directive to relax certain conditions for pharmacists (e.g., extension of prescriptions beyond the maximum durations; prescribing a medication for all minor conditions as long as the initial diagnosis by the physician was in the past 4 years; waiving the obligation to communicate to the physician prescription extensions, adjustments or substitutions; substituting medications to avoid shortages)

Issued new directives for pharmacists (e.g., assessing the physical and mental condition of a person in order to ensure the appropriate use of medication; taking a sample by inserting an instrument into the pharynx; prescribing an over-the-counter medication when the clinical situation or any other circumstance justifies it; administering medication for vaccination; administering medication during an emergency; prescribing medication during vaccination; prescribing in an emergency requiring the administration of salbutamol)
Provided safety guidelines for midwives to assess risks by performing a triage before each face-to-face contact

intervention.who: Ordre professionnel de la physiothérapie du Québec
intervention.what: Reinstated licences of physiotherapists who are under the age of 70 and were members of the order in the past 5 years, so they can work with clients

intervention.who: Ordre professionnel de la physiothérapie du Québec
intervention.what: Published guidelines and resources for physiotherapists to support provision of telehealth for non-urgent care
Issued directive for midwives to temporarily cancel home births

intervention.who: Minister of Health and Social Services
intervention.what: Extended the public health state of emergency

intervention.who: Minister of health and social services
intervention.what: Prohibited all gatherings, with the exception of transportation, services and workplaces where distances of 2 metres between individuals are maintained
Introduced automated calls made at 6 p.m. to those aged 70 and over reminding them of the importance of respecting public health guidelines

intervention.who: Ordre des infirmières et infirmiers auxiliaires du Québec
intervention.what: Launched an invitation to former licensed practical nurses, with instructions on how to reinstate licences free of cost for members who meet certain criteria
Published resources for occupational therapists to support provision of telehealth for non-urgent care.

intervention.who: Société des établissements de plein air du Québec
intervention.what: Closed access to national parks, wildlife reserves and tourist establishments

intervention.who: Minister of health and social services
intervention.what: Amended the employment conditions that apply to non-unionized salaried personnel in national and local provisions of the collective agreements in force in the health and social services network to enable the employer to meet the needs of the population
Strongly discouraged short trips within Que. in an effort to not "spread COVID-19 from 1 region to another, from 1 city to another, and even from 1 district to another"

intervention.who: Minister of education and higher education
intervention.what: Extended closure of educational institutions (elementary and secondary schools, training centres, private schools)

intervention.who: Minister of health and social services
intervention.what: Ordered closure of retail businesses located in shopping centres, except for (a) food  stores, pharmacies and Société des alcools du Québec outlets; (b) businesses with an exterior door that makes it possible to access the business directly without going through the common areas of the shopping centre; and (3) beauty and personal care salons, including, in particular, hairdressing salons and manicure and pedicure salons

intervention.who: Minister of health and social services
intervention.what: Suspended food consumption in dining rooms and restaurants

intervention.who: Minister of health and social services
intervention.what: Published testing criteria to include 1) symptomatic travellers, case contacts and contacts of symptomatic travellers; 2) hospitalized patients with clinical or radiological presentation consistent with a diagnosis of COVID-19; 3) health professionals who are in direct contact with clients as well as ambulance services AND those who present symptoms consistent with SARS-CoV-2 infection AND who are likely to have been exposed to customers or whose withdrawal would cause a break in services; 4) residents of nursing homes and long-term care and private residences for seniors with symptoms consistent with infection with SARS-CoV-2 OR in the presence of a potential outbreak of respiratory infection (at least 2 cases) or unexpected death with a suspected infectious respiratory cause

intervention.who: Minister of health and social services
intervention.what: Suspended all visits to residential and long-term care centres and private seniors’ residences.
Adopted guidelines for resident physicians who have completed their training without passing all examinations to obtain a restrictive licence.

intervention.who: Minister of health and social services
intervention.what: Encouraged organizations providing non-priority services to engage in teleworking and e-commerce
Updated automated calls made at 6 p.m. to those aged 60 and over reminding them of the importance of respecting public health guidelines
Non-essential travel between regions of Quebec must stop, particularly in Montréal and the Eastern Townships.
Issued criteria for physicians who would like to re-instate their licence and wish to return to practice at no cost to the physician
Announced checkpoints set up near the US border to inform returning travellers of the need to self-isolate for 14 days

A public health ordinance will be in force allowing only essential travel to Bas-Saint-Laurent; Abitibi-Témiscamingue; the North Shore; Nord-du-Québec; Saguenay–Lac-Saint-Jean; Gaspésie-Îles-de-la-Madeleine; Nunavik; the Terres-Cries-de-la-Baie-James. Police checkpoints will be installed to turn away non-essential travellers.

intervention.who: Minister of health and social services
intervention.what: Extended the public health state of emergency

intervention.who: Minister of health and social services
intervention.what: Prohibited all gatherings. Exceptions for transportation, service delivery and workplaces must ensure that distances of 2 metres between individuals are maintained.
CEGEP and university students will complete the session online using virtual learning.
Published updated guidance for physicians on how to provide telemedicine.
Extension of the closure of all non-essential organizations and businesses
Announced that pregnant women cannot be accompanied by anyone at the Jewish General Hospital in Montréal due to a high prevalence of COVID-19 cases in Montréal.

intervention.who: Minister of health and social services
intervention.what: Extended the public health state of emergency

intervention.who: Minister of health and social services
intervention.what: Extension of state of emergency that prohibited gatherings, with further instruction that any gatherings must ensure that distances of 2 metres between individuals are maintained
Published recommendations for wearing homemade masks in public spaces

intervention.who: Collège des médecins du Québec, Ordre professionnel de la physiothérapie du Québec
intervention.what: Updated service guidelines to allow physiotherapists to take nasopharyngeal and oropharyngeal swabs from patients in screening clinics
Reinstated licences of occupational therapists who are under the age of 70 and were members of the order in the past 5 years, so they can work with clients

intervention.who: Ordre des infirmières et infirmiers du Québec
intervention.what: Waived or modified registration requirements, allowing nurses who wish to return to the profession to do so at no cost

intervention.who: Minister of health and social services
intervention.what: Announced that caregivers who meet certain criteria are allowed to visit and provide care to a loved one in senior homes.

Granted permission to all physicians who would like to work in long-term care facilities, even without institutional status, as long as physicians are matched with experienced physicians in long-term care environments

intervention.who: Ordre professionnel des inhalothérapeutes du Québec
intervention.what: Issued criteria for retired/inactive/student respiratory therapists, to allow them to apply for temporary registration during the pandemic
Granted a $4 million loan to Medicom, a company that is accelerating the establishment of a factory that will produce millions of N95 masks and level 3 surgical masks starting in July 2020.

intervention.who: Minister of health and social services
intervention.what: Announced operation of 3 designated clinics for screening and treatment of COVID-19, with 15 more scheduled to open in the upcoming week
Requests that the Quebec population not use masks so as to not cause a shortage among health care workers and affected patients
Announced that Quebec health care system has freed up 4,000 hospital beds because elective health care procedures were postponed
Recommended that all private practice occupational therapists postpone all non-urgent appointments
Requested that Quebec companies manufacture certain equipment, in the event that orders from elsewhere are cancelled.

intervention.type: Public information — launch of web page/resource
intervention.what: Launched a dedicated government web page for COVID-19 (earliest publication date tracked using Wayback Machine)

intervention.type: Public information — launch of web page/resource
intervention.who: Institut national de santé publique du Québec
intervention.what: Launched a dedicated web page for COVID-19 (earliest publication date tracked using Wayback Machine)

intervention.who: Ordre professionnel des technologistes médicaux du Québec
intervention.what: Issued criteria for retired/inactive/graduating medical laboratory technologists to allow them to apply for temporary registration during the pandemic
Called on Quebeckers to avoid non-essential trips from 1 region to another
Ordered the closure of all non-essential organizations and businesses

intervention.who: Minister of health and social services
intervention.what: Authorized the Commission de la construction du Québec to exercise its supervisory powers for the purpose of verifying the application of certain measures in the COVID-19 Guide for Construction Sites

intervention.who: Minister of health and social services
intervention.what: Issued an order that any person may be redeployed to perform other duties or functions within the health and social services network even if the person's level of employment is not respected for the duties to be assigned to the person, with the exception of personnel whose work duties are considered essential

intervention.who: Minister of health and social services
intervention.what: Extended the public health state of emergency

intervention.who: Minister of health and social services
intervention.what: Issued an order authorizing nurses to perform the COVID-19 screening test, even without a prescription
Announced an extension to all COVID-19 salary bonuses granted to health care workers, which were due to end on April 30
Announced that volunteers who can work full time in public long-term care homes will receive a salary and bonuses equivalent to $21.28 an hour, or $3,368 per month
Announced that retail stores and stores with exterior entrances, excluding those in the greater Montréal region will reopen
Announced that the construction (excluding residential construction) and manufacturing sectors will reopen with shift restrictions (maximum of 50 workers + 50% of surplus employees)
Announced that manufacturing companies will reopen without restrictions (100% of employees)
Presented a gradual plan for withdrawal of police checkpoints and lifting travel restrictions for Laurentians, Lanaudière, Chaudière-Appalaches and the city of Rouyn-Noranda

Announced that elementary schools will begin reopening on May 11 outside of Montréal and on May 19 in Montréal. High schools, colleges and universities will not reopen until September. Subsequently postponed (see QC170).
Announced that the reopening of retail businesses and stores with exterior entrances in the greater Montréal region has been postponed to May 18

Announced that, subject to compliance with specific conditions, a significant caregiver (i.e., someone who was already present on a regular basis before the pandemic) will be able to provide support to a person both in shelters and long-term care homes as an intermediate and family-type resource or in a private residence for seniors

Announced that, for humanitarian and human dignity reasons, the ban on visits to palliative care units in residential and long-term care homes, private residences for seniors and intermediate and family-type resources is lifted. A maximum of 3 people per 24-hour period will be authorized for these visits, 1 to 2 significant people at a time.

Agreed, in partnership with the Federation of Medical Specialists of Quebec, to favour deployment applications from physicians who can commit to a facility on a full-time basis in order to maintain clinical coordination in all establishments
Updated recommendations to wear a mask in public places when physical distance of 2 metres is not possible, (e.g. public transport)

Authorized the resumption of university research activities related to the fields of health, natural sciences, agriculture, forestry and engineering, as well as seasonal outdoor activities. These will be done in accordance with the public health recommendations.
Announced that daycares will begin reopening on May 11 outside of Montréal and on May 19 in Montréal (subsequently postponed). High schools, colleges and universities will not reopen until September.
Announced that retail stores and stores with exterior entrances in the greater Montréal region will reopen. Subsequently postponed (see QC129).

Presented a gradual plan for withdrawal of police checkpoints and lifting travel restrictions for Outaouais, with the exception of Gatineau, Abitibi-Témiscamingue, La Tuque and Saguenay–Lac-Saint-Jean
Presented a gradual plan for withdrawal of police checkpoints and lifting travel restrictions for Bas-Saint-Laurent, Gaspésie, Îles-de-la-Madeleine, Charlevoix and Côte-Nord

intervention.who: Minister of health and social services
intervention.what: Announced emergency assistance of $3 million for public and private long-term care homes to cover costs of increased surveillance, improved sanitation and disinfection, the purchase of sanitary equipment, the hiring of additional resources, the payment of overtime as well as for the increase in costs related to feeding residents

intervention.who: Minister of health and social services
intervention.what: Announced the creation of transitional places set up in already existing facilities or in non-traditional sites to accommodate patients who have been hospitalized (because they tested positive for COVID-19 or may potentially show symptoms) before they are transferred to their living environment (i.e., residential and long-term care homes, intermediate and family-type resources, in a private seniors' residence, in a continuing assistance residence or in any other living environment)

intervention.who: Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux
intervention.what: Implemented a new diagnostic plan for prioritizing screening for COVID-19: 1) symptomatic patients (e.g., those hospitalized or requiring regular care such as hemodialysis or pregnant women in the 3rd trimester and people who must accompany them to a delivery, if symptomatic); 2) symptomatic health professionals; 3) users and staff in accommodation settings and those who are directed to new living environments, symptomatic people living in at-risk environments (e.g. homeless shelters) and in environments hosting elderly people (over 70); 4) symptomatic people from all communities; 5) first responders or workers in the public security system and other symptomatic essential workers; 6) close contacts of cases, symptomatic or asymptomatic

intervention.who: Ordre des orthophonistes et audiologistes du Québec
intervention.what: Requested members working in private practice (not included in the list of businesses to reopen, as per government announcement 2020-04-28) to respect government restrictions and limit all in-person appointments to emergencies only. Members working in publicly funded care settings are asked to cooperate with their employer and assist as needed to manage the crisis (recommendation unchanged). All members encouraged to practise telemedicine if appropriate.
Published resources for optometrists practising virtual care, for both urgent and non-urgent purposes
Published resources for occupational therapist clinics to start planning for possible reopening with special hygiene measures

intervention.who: Ordre professionnel des diététistes du Québec
intervention.what: Announced that retired dietitians who meet certain criteria may temporarily reinstate their licences, allowing them to provide dietetic services
Called chiropractors to support Le Centre intégré de santé et de services sociaux (CISSS) de la Montérégie-Est as needed

intervention.who: Ordre des dentistes du Québec and Ordre des hygiénistes dentaires du Québec
intervention.what: Issued a call for willing dental hygienists to work in long-term care homes

intervention.who: Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux
intervention.what: Updated case definition with definitions on COVID-19-related deaths

Permitted directors of correctional facilities to authorize, under certain conditions, the temporary absence of an inmate serving a prison term of less than 2 years in order to protect the inmate's health and that of the other inmates and members of the personnel

Improved staff compensation to encourage full-time work and the retention of health care workers by investing nearly $70 million per month for additional premiums in long-term care facilities and hospitals that are considered "hot zones"

intervention.who: Minister of health and social services
intervention.what: Authorized audiologists, dentists, dieticians-nutritionists, dental hygienists, speech therapists and physiotherapists to take samples for the COVID-19 screening tests

intervention.who: Minister of health and social services
intervention.what: Extended the public health state of emergency
Announced that individual sports and recreational activities that take place outside, without physical contact, such as tennis and golf, may resume

intervention.who: Minister of health and social services
intervention.what: Expanded scope of practice for specialized nurse practitioners to complete the formalities necessary for the preventive withdrawal of a pregnant or breastfeeding worker, the preventive withdrawal of a worker exposed to a contaminant or to an environment that puts their condition at risk, and the preventive withdrawal of certain home child care providers who are pregnant or breastfeeding
Quebec will not reopen schools in the territory of the metropolitan community of Montréal before the end of August
Postponed the opening of daycare centres in the metropolitan community of Montréal to June 1

intervention.who: Minister of health and social services
intervention.what: Extended the deadline for respiratory therapists to be authorized to perform the COVID-19 screening test even without a prescription for a period equivalent to that of the public health emergency

intervention.who: Minister of health and social services
intervention.what: Extended the deadline for midwives to be authorized to fulfill the obligations and complete the formalities entrusted to the physician or specialized nurse practitioner for a period equivalent to that of the public health emergency

intervention.who: Minister of health and social services
intervention.what: Gradual resumption of medically assisted procreation services
Permitted businesses with an external door to reopen in the metropolitan community of Montréal
Announced the resumption of surgical activities; establishments will need to ensure that they have both the necessary staff and technical facilities, including a sufficient number of available beds
Increased the limit on outdoor gatherings to 10 people or fewer and can include people from a maximum of 3 households
Announced the resumption of private health services including dental care, optometry, physiotherapy and osteopathy in all areas

intervention.who: Minister of health and social services
intervention.what: Extended the public health state of emergency

Permitted museum institutions, public library loan counters and movie theatres to resume their activities at their own pace

intervention.who: Minister of health and social services
intervention.what: Authorized nursing assistants, medical technologists and midwives to perform the COVID-19 screening test even without a prescription

intervention.who: Minister of health and social services
intervention.what: Authorized midwives to perform and interpret a glycated hemoglobin test in relation to the mother and to prescribe various analyses necessary for preeclampsia screening

intervention.who: Minister of health and social services, minister of education and higher education
intervention.what: Announced an increase in the number of new registrations (139 new admissions) in doctoral training programs in medicine over a 3-year period
Permitted shopping centres to reopen outside the metropolitan community of Montréal
Launching a major campaign to recruit and train 10,000 people who would like to become orderlies; training will run from mid-June to mid-September

intervention.who: Minister of health and social services
intervention.what: Extended the public health state of emergency

intervention.who: Minister of health and social services
intervention.what: Permitting all camping and outfitting establishments to resume their activities

intervention.who: Minister of health and social services
intervention.what: Permitting the reopening of all tourist residences outside the metropolitan community of Montréal and Joliette including those offered on the sites of the Société des establishments de plein air du Québec (Sépaq)

intervention.who: Minister of health and social services
intervention.what: Extended the duration of the privileges granted to a physician or a dentist that expire between the date of the order and the end of the public health emergency to a period equivalent to that of the public health emergency

intervention.who: Minister of health and social services
intervention.what: Authorized midwives to prescribe or administer the following medications: (1) vancomycin for group B streptococcus prophylaxis during labour; (2) azithromycin for the treatment of chlamydia and gonorrhea; (3) valacyclovir for prophylaxis of recurrent herpes; and (4) domperidone, exclusively for breastfeeding

Announced the resumption of personal and beauty care enterprises (hairdressing and esthetic services) in all areas except the metropolitan community of Montréal and Joliette, which will be announced at a later date
Announced the resumption of pet grooming services in all areas

Provided chiropractors with safety guidelines for reopening

intervention.what: Confirmed that all physiotherapists must change their gowns between patients and that masks are mandatory for both patients and providers

Ordered the minimization of all non-priority health services. Remaining services include physicians, and dentists and optometrists for emergency consultations only.

intervention.who: Ordre des orthophonistes et audiologistes du Québec

Support guide for physicians released on implementation of telemedicine in the context of a pandemic

intervention.who: Minister of health and social services
intervention.what: Together with the ministry of education, the government is announcing an increase in the number of new registrations (139 new admissions) in medicine.

intervention.who: Minister of health and social services
intervention.what: Reopening of outdoor public spaces, such as outdoor pools and module park games, including water games, for the entire summer period in all regions of Quebec

intervention.who: Minister of health and social services

intervention.who: Minister of health and social services

intervention.who: Minister of health and social services
intervention.what: Introduced the first caregiver bill in Quebec history, which standardizes the definition of a caregiver and requires that an impact assessment on caregivers be considered when government departments make legislative or regulatory proposals. The bill also provides for the establishment of a Quebec caregiver observatory to better understand the habits of caregivers and to study the impacts of measures put in place by the government over time.

intervention.who: Minister of health and social services
intervention.what: Permitted indoor gatherings of up to 50 people. A distance of 2 metres is recommended between people; however, in seated places (e.g., classrooms, theatres and movie theatres), a physical distance of 1.5 metres will be allowed. Children 16 and under may also be at a distance of 1 metre from each other.

intervention.who: Office of the minister of education and higher education
intervention.what: Announced operational plan for fall reopenings for schools including updates on case management for these institutions: classes will no longer need to be divided into subgroups of a maximum of 6 students; students must maintain a physical distance of 2 metres with members of the school staff and other groups of students but do not need to maintain physical distancing between students within the same classroom; all students must return to in-person learning (exceptions for students with medical conditions or living with someone with a medical condition, who will have distance learning made available to them); masks are mandatory for all students from grade 5 up as well as for all members of the school staff when travelling within the school or on school public transport; masks are not mandatory inside the classroom or cafeterias

For regions of the MRC de Portneuf in the health region of the Capitale-Nationale and the MRCs of Drummond, Bécancour and Nicolet-Yamaska and the city of Trois-Rivières from the Mauricie et Centre-du-Québec Health Region in the red level, it is now mandatory for schools to reduce class hours by 50% for students in grades 10 and 11 and provide distance learning to compensate for reduced hours. Wearing of a face covering will be compulsory at all times for students attending a secondary school, including on the grounds outside the establishments and inside the classroom. A procedural mask is also compulsory for all school staff in common areas, particularly at all times in staff rooms (except for eating or drinking) and on the school grounds if they cannot respect the 2-metre distance. Students must return to a single stable class group at all times. Extracurricular and inter-school activities as well as school trips will be suspended. Only activities carried out in free practice, on an individual basis or in pairs, will be permitted. No group activity, match or competition will be allowed.

For the city of Gatineau and the MRC des Collines-de-l'Outaouais in the Outaouais region, which are in the red level, it is now mandatory for schools to reduce class hours by 50% for students in grades 10 and 11 and provide distance learning to compensate for reduced hours. intervention.what: Announced that for the entire health region of Saguenay–Lac-Saint-Jean, the entire Chaudière-Appalaches region and the MRCs of Montmagny, Islet and Etchemins, it is now mandatory for schools to reduce class hours by 50% for students in grades 10 and 11 and provide distance learning to compensate for reduced hours. Wearing of a face covering will be compulsory at all times for students attending a secondary school, including on the grounds outside the establishments and inside the classroom. A procedural mask is also compulsory for all school staff in common areas, particularly at all times in staff rooms (except for eating or drinking) and on the school grounds if they cannot respect the 2-metre distance. Students must return to a single stable class group at all times. Extracurricular and inter-school activities as well as school trips will be suspended. Only activities carried out in free practice, on an individual basis or in pairs, will be permitted. No group activity, match or competition will be allowed.

Testing is recommended for individuals with symptoms compatible with COVID-19 AND symptom onset within 14 days of exposure: travel outside Canada, including United States; travel within Canada to B.C., Alta., Ont., Que.; travel within Canada to any province and attended a mass gathering; health care workers (including but not limited to Saskatchewan Health Authority staff); prioritize for same day testing, but not until >24 hours after symptom onset (to minimize false negatives); contacts of cases, even if case was reported outside of Saskatchewan; hospitalized with respiratory illness, especially if no other cause; consider repeat testing if initial test negative; outbreaks in long-term care facilities

intervention.who: Government of Saskatchewan, Chief Medical Health Officer
intervention.what: Closed all gyms, fitness centres, casinos and bingo halls until further notice

intervention.who: Government of Saskatchewan, Chief Medical Health Officer
intervention.what: Ordered all restaurants, bars and event venues to limit their seating to 50% of capacity or up to a maximum of 50 people, whichever is lesser
Prohibited gatherings of more than 50 people
Announced that a new payment code for virtual care by secure video link is available with physicians who offer that option.
Declared a provincial state of emergency

intervention.who: College of Dental Surgeons of Saskatchewan
intervention.what: Strongly recommended suspension of all non-essential/non-emergency dental treatment and services.
Ordered mandatory self-isolation for 14 days for individuals diagnosed with COVID-19

Waived or modified registration requirements for former registered nurses and nurse practitioners, allowing them to apply for temporary registration during the pandemic on an expedited basis and at no cost. Licence to be valid for 90 days with opportunity for extension as needed.

Self-isolation is required for 14 days after returning from travel outside Canada; for individuals who have been in close contact with a person with COVID-19; and for individuals who are diagnosed with COVID-19 and well enough to stay at home.
Closure of elementary, middle and high schools; suspension of classes
Closed in-person park facility services

Travellers returning to Sask. from outside Canada are required to self-isolate for 14 days. Violation of the order may result in a $2,000 fine. Anyone identified as a close contact of someone with COVID-19 is required to self-isolate for 14 days from date of contact.

Child care centres co-located in schools will remain operational and open spaces exclusively to workers who are associated with the pandemic responses who need child care during the COVID-19 pandemic.
Published case definition, which aligns with the national case definition

intervention.who: Government of Saskatchewan, Chief Medical Health Officer; Work Safe Saskatchewan
intervention.what: Announced that all non-essential employees in Government of Saskatchewan ministries, agencies and Crown corporations will be part of a phased-in work-from-home policy. This requires any employee able to work from home to do so immediately. All non-government workers are encouraged to work from home where possible.
Discontinued all non-urgent/elective surgeries, procedures and diagnostics.
Closed park facilities (all person-staffed buildings and desks, visitor centres, washrooms, picnic areas, as well as campgrounds and campsites)

intervention.who: Government of Saskatchewan, Chief Medical Health Officer
intervention.what: Services ordered closed and only allowed delivery/takeout: restaurants, food courts, cafeterias, cafes, bistros and similar facilities. Exceptions are takeout with 2-metre distancing between customers during pickup; drive-through food services; delivery of food products; soup kitchens, not-for-profit community and religious kitchens with 2-metre distancing between tables. Closures of all personal service facilities including tattooists, hairdressers, barbers, cosmetologists, electrologists, estheticians, manicurists, pedicurists, suntanning parlours, facilities performing body piercing, bone grafting or scarification services.

intervention.who: Government of Saskatchewan, Chief Medical Health Officer
intervention.what: Ordered closure of dental, optometrist, chiropractic, physical therapists, registered massage therapy, acupuncturists, acupressurists and podiatry clinics except for non-elective procedures

Daycare facilities limited to maximum of 8 children unless they can configure the facility so that a maximum of 8 children are kept in room and be in accordance with the Saskatchewan child care guidelines for care. All daycares that are co-located with a long-term care or personal care home that meet the above restriction shall be segregated with a private entrance so that there are no shared common areas with the home and no interaction between daycare children and residents of the facility.

intervention.type: Public information — launch of web page/resource
intervention.what: Launched a phone line to answer non-health-specific COVID-19 questions (e.g., travel restrictions)

intervention.who: Government of Saskatchewan, Chief Medical Health Officer
intervention.what: Updated list of services and workers deemed essential. Services and businesses now considered non-essential and ordered to only allow pickup/delivery: clothing stores; shoe stores; flower shops; sporting good and adventure stores; vaping supply shops; boats, ATV or snowmobile retailers; gift, book or stationary stores; jewelry and accessory stores; toy stores; music, electronic and entertainment stores; pawn shops; and travel agencies.

intervention.who: Government of Saskatchewan, Chief Medical Health Officer
intervention.what: Prohibited gatherings of more than 10 people
Redeployed government staff to address capacity need for contact tracing
Suspended campsite reservation, and opening suspended

All critically ill patients are suspected to be COVID-19 positive until proven otherwise. Assessing for signs of life can no longer include listening or feeling for breathing by placing your ear and cheek close to the patient’s mouth.

Provided $2.88 million, with $110,000 to each of the 12 MN-S regions, as the first relief response of COVID-19. This interim funding provides some relief for the immediate needs for Métis families in the area of child care, personal protective equipment, regional capacity and Métis households in financial distress. Funding breakdowns include the following:

intervention.who: Government of Saskatchewan, Saskatchewan Health Authority
intervention.what: Released projections for cases and critical care capacity
Spring breaks in Sask. regions follow the same schedule. Saskatoon Public Schools example provided.

Mandated daily screening of staff, physicians, learners, trainees, vendors and contractors before entering any SHA facility (including long-term care facilities, hospitals, primary care sites) or program area, to ensure they do not have any influenza-like illness
Mandated that staff and physicians who work in patient/client/resident care areas or travel through those areas must wear a mask at all times
Recommended that all northern Saskatchewan residents returning from northern Alberta self-isolate for 14 days upon return

Advised against all non-essential travel between northwest Saskatchewan and northern Alberta. This is in response to cases linked to travel between northwest Saskatchewan and Alberta, and reports of a number of COVID-19 cases identified at an oil sands facility north of Fort McMurray.

intervention.who: Saskatchewan Association of Licensed Practical Nurses
intervention.what: Waived or modified registration requirements for former licensed practical nurses, allowing them to apply for temporary registration during the pandemic on an expedited basis and at no cost

Waived or modified registration requirements for former paramedics, allowing them to apply for temporary registration during the pandemic on an expedited basis and at no cost. Licence valid for 90 days.

intervention.who: Ministry of Health, Saskatchewan Health Authority
intervention.what: Announced introduction of COVID-19 assessment sites over the coming days

intervention.who: Ministry of Health, Saskatchewan Health Authority
intervention.what: Announced increased access to testing through the creation of 38 testing sites around the province and tripled the staff available for contact tracing efforts to detect and prevent community transmission

intervention.who: Saskatchewan Society of Medical Laboratory Technologists
intervention.what: Waived or modified registration requirements for former registered medical laboratory technologists, allowing them to apply for temporary registration during the pandemic on an expedited basis and at no cost

intervention.who: College of Physicians and Surgeons of Saskatchewan
intervention.what: Published information on modification of registration requirements for non-practising/retired/out-of-province physicians, allowing them to apply for return to practice during the pandemic on an expedited basis and at no cost
Published information on emergency registration requirements for retired/inactive/out-of-province/student respiratory therapists, allowing them to apply for temporary registration during the pandemic
Extended the provincial state of emergency
Extended the provincial state of emergency
Released 5-stage "Re-Open Saskatchewan" plan to gradually reopen businesses and services

Announced resumption of public access to dentistry, optometry, physical therapy, optician services, podiatry, occupational therapy and chiropractic treatment; and resumption of access to medical spas for therapeutic services provided by a licensed medical practitioner for Saskatchewan residents; communities of Lloydminster and La Loche excluded

Resumption of low-risk outdoor recreational activities (fishing and boating); public access to provincial parks to resume for fishing, boating, hiking and mountain biking, but other services will remain restricted; communities of Lloydminster and La Loche excluded

intervention.who: Premier, Chief Medical Officer of Health
intervention.what: Permitted golf courses and drive-in theatres to open; community of La Loche excluded

intervention.who: Premier, Chief Medical Officer of Health
intervention.what: Permitted opening of public and private campgrounds at 50% capacity; community of La Loche excluded
Permitted households to spend time with 1 or 2 other households, forming an extended household group
Restricted non-essential travel to northern Saskatchewan and set up checkpoints on highways. Recommended against travel between northern communities.
Expansion of availability of child care centres beyond pandemic response workers only — now available to families returning to work to a capacity of 8 children per room.

Further restrictions for travel in and to northern Saskatchewan. All non-critical travel to northern communities and travel between communities is no longer permitted. Exceptions for travel for groceries and medical appointments.

Provided $400 wage supplement for essential workers caring for vulnerable populations who are earning less than $2,500/month and working for senior-care facilities or home care, licenced child care facilities, group homes run by community-based organizations, and emergency shelters and transition shelters

Released guidance on religious services — drive-in services to be permitted as long as people remain in their vehicles and only 1 family is in each car. Not clear on what date nor during which phase this will be permitted.
Released 4-phase plan to resume health services
Announced resumption of 6-week urgent surgeries, routine immunizations and mental health and addictions programs. Increase of outpatient volumes for MRI and CT scans.
Updated projections for cases and critical care capacity
Released interim protocol for safe return to practice

intervention.who: College of Dental Surgeons of Saskatchewan
intervention.what: Updated interim protocol to support the gradual return to practice. Protocol includes training and personal protective equipment requirements that practices must meet prior to offering non-emergency dental care.
Provided expedited emergency registration/licensure at no cost for retired, associate and non-practising members and pharmacy professionals who were previously registered/licensed

intervention.who: College of Physicians and Surgeons of Saskatchewan
intervention.what: Announced that physicians may apply for COVID-19 Emergency Scope of Practice, which enables them to expand their scope of practice related to service delivery

intervention.who: Government of Saskatchewan, Chief Medical Health Officer
intervention.what: Closures of all recreational and entertainment facilities including fitness centres, casinos, bingo halls, arenas, curling rinks, swimming pools, galleries, theatres, museums and similar facilities
Suspended in-class learning until September
Extended the provincial state of emergency

Expanded testing criteria to include all residents working outside of home. Proactive testing of all patients upon or in advance of a planned admission to an acute care hospital for a stay greater than 24 hours, immunocompromised asymptomatic individuals, all health staff working with immunocompromised patients and workers in high volume work settings (factories and industrial settings).
Permitted hairdresser and barbershops, retail businesses, shopping malls, public markets and farmers' markets to open; community of La Loche excluded
Permitted services from registered massage therapists, acupuncturists and acupressurists; community of La Loche excluded
Resumed outpatient physiotherapy and home care services
Recommended wearing a non-medical mask in community settings where distancing is not possible
Permitted gyms and fitness facilities to open; community of La Loche excluded

Permitted additional personal businesses to open that were not included in the 2020-05-19 Phase 2 reopenings (e.g., estheticians, tattoo artists, make-up applicators, manicurists); opened places of worship; community of La Loche excluded
Increased the limit on outdoor gatherings to 30 people or fewer; increased the limit on indoor gatherings to 15 people or fewer; northwest Saskatchewan excluded
Permitted all child care centres to open, and increased capacity limit to 15 children per room
Amended travel restrictions to Northern Saskatchewan Administration District to only its northwestern region
Announced $2.3 million in support of the ongoing effort to combat COVID-19 in northwestern Saskatchewan, including supporting security checkpoints in impacted communities

intervention.who: College of Dental Surgeons of Saskatchewan

Updated case definition of suspect and probable cases, which aligns with the national case definition

Lifted travel restrictions on northwest Saskatchewan
Increased the limit on outdoor gatherings in northwest Saskatchewan to 20 people, with physical distancing requirements

Announced that long-term care residents may have 2 designated support persons in cases where having only 1 will impact quality of life (visits remain restricted to compassionate care); outpatients and family members/support persons will be provided with a medical grade mask and asked to wear it while in Saskatchewan Health Authority homes and facilities

Added all critical care and intensive care patients to the definition of compassionate care (for whom visitors are permitted). Expanded family presence for palliative care to allow for 2 people at the same time. Outpatients and family members/support persons will be provided with a medical grade mask and asked to wear it while in Saskatchewan Health Authority homes and facilities.
Permitted outdoor playgrounds and beaches and associated washrooms to open, community of La Loche excluded
Announced further increases to surgical capacity, medical imaging capacity and specialty clinic testing

Permitted outdoor pools and splash pads and outdoor sports and activities to open, community of La Loche excluded
Increased limit on indoor gatherings to 30 people with physical distancing requirements, northwest Saskatchewan excluded

Resumed public access to dentistry, optometry, physical therapy, optician services, podiatry, occupational therapy and chiropractic treatment as part of the Phase 1 reopening in Lloydminster; resumption of access to medical spas for therapeutic services provided by a licensed medical practitioner for Saskatchewan residents

In the village of La Loche, resumption of public access to dentistry, optometry, physical therapy, optician services, podiatry, occupational therapy and chiropractic treatment; resumption of access to medical spas for therapeutic services provided by a licensed medical practitioner for Saskatchewan residents

In Lloydminster, resumed low-risk outdoor recreational activities (fishing and boating); public access to provincial parks to resume for fishing, boating, hiking and mountain biking, but other services will remain restricted

In the village of La Loche, resumed low-risk outdoor recreational activities (fishing and boating); public access to provincial parks to resume for fishing, boating, hiking and mountain biking, but other services will remain restricted; opened golf courses, drive-in theatres, as well as campgrounds at 50% capacity
In the village of La Loche, permitted hairdressers and barbershops, retail businesses, shopping malls, public markets and farmers' markets to open.
In the village of La Loche, permitted services for registered massage therapists, acupuncturists and acupressurists to open
Implemented policy for infection prevention and control at all chiropractic clinics
Issued interim directives for dental hygenists to reduce the risk of transmission and enable safe reopening of services

intervention.type: Public information — phase and alert level changes

Permitted libraries, museums, galleries, movie theatres and live theatres to open; community of La Loche excluded

Permitted indoor pools, rinks, sports and activities and the performing arts to reopen
Permitted casinos and bingo halls to reopen

Increased seating capacity limit for restaurants and licensed establishments to a level that allows staff and customers to maintain 2-metre physical distance; permitted video lottery terminals, pool tables, dart boards, arcade games and other recreation areas in these businesses to reopen

Permitted patients and residents in acute and long-term care, personal care and group home settings to have 2 designated visitors, 1 of whom may visit at a time; visitation is no longer limited to compassionate care only

Permitted live music in restaurants, licensed establishments and public and farmers' markets to resume with distancing and safety measures in place; permitted banquet and conference facilities to reopen
Permitted racetracks, rodeos and car and trade shows to reopen

Reduced the required distance between vehicles at drive-in theatres from 5 metres to 2 metres
Permitted fitness facilities to allow 24-hour access with registration of guests to facilitate contact tracing
Permitted yard and garage sales, door-to-door canvassing and sales to reopen
Expanded testing criteria to allow anyone to request a test, whether they have COVID-19 symptoms or not

intervention.who: College of Dental Surgeons of Saskatchewan
intervention.what: Updated interim infection control protocol for dental professions: use of personal protective equipment during aerosol-generating procedures, staggered appointment times, open concept operatories, etc.
Suspended emergency registration for pharmacists; current emergency licences will remain valid for the 90-day period
Extended the provincial state of emergency
Extended the provincial state of emergency
Extended the provincial state of emergency

Opened public schools for the first day of classes
Encouraged all school teachers and staff to seek testing prior to returning to school and at frequent points throughout the year; targeted testing of school staff will be used as a monitoring program

intervention.who: Ministry of Education, public health officials
intervention.what: Released parent information packages with detailed fact sheets on COVID-19 testing options and processes for notification of illness in school; students will be given voluntary testing in schools throughout the school year, with parental consent; 2 cases in a single classroom will result in a change to non-classroom learning

intervention.what: Released parent information packages for distribution prior to the September 8 school year start; includes background on Safe Schools Plan, guidance on how to prepare for return and information regarding thresholds for changes to in-classroom learning; children are recommended to wear masks in school and will be educated on 2-metre distancing
Announced that the Health Canada COVID Alert app is available to Saskatchewan residents, which will allow subscribers to receive digital COVID-19 exposure alerts
Extended the provincial state of emergency
Extended the provincial state of emergency
Extended the provincial state of emergency
Extended the provincial state of emergency

Defined an outbreak in a non-household setting as 2 or more people testing positive for COVID‐19 when all are linked to a specific non-household setting (including but not limited to hospitals, long-term care and integrated facilities, personal care homes, correctional facilities, homeless shelters, group homes, congregate/communal living settings, mass gatherings, events, workplaces, places of worship, daycares, universities, colleges, schools) or event within a specified time period

intervention.type: Public information — phase and alert level changes
intervention.what: All regions except the communities of Lloydminster and La Loche entered Phase 1, the initial easing of restrictions

Expanded mandatory indoor masking in public places to all Saskatchewan communities with populations of 5,000 people or greater, including neighbouring communities or municipalities situated around the largest urban centres of Saskatoon, Regina and Prince Albert, even if their independent populations are fewer than 5,000 residents
Required all restaurants and licensed establishments (bars, taverns, nightclubs) to stop serving alcohol by 10 p.m. and prohibited consumption after 11 p.m.
Limited all aerobic group fitness activities (i.e., spin classes, class circuit training, aquasize) to a maximum of 8 participants
Prohibited indoor gatherings of more than 15 people in private dwellings, excluding families who co-habitate
Prohibited consumption of alcohol in all nightclubs after 10 p.m.; nightclubs must close by 11 p.m. except for takeout/delivery
Prohibited indoor gatherings of more than 10 people in private dwellings, including those who regularly live there
Extended the provincial state of emergency
Extended the provincial state of emergency
Extended the provincial state of emergency
Recommended school divisions move to level 3 (reduced in-class learning) in their back-to-school plans for high schools with 600 students or more
Permitted dietitians in Saskatchewan to perform nasopahryngeal swabbing
Published clarification that physiotherapists are able to perform nasopahryngeal swabbing following the training completed within accredited physiotherapy programs
Suspended applications for emergency practising licences for nurses

Required all restaurants and licensed establishments (bars, taverns, nightclubs) to limit seating to 4 people at a single table; tables must be 2 metres apart if there is an impermeable barrier and 3 metres apart if there is no barrier; contact information must be collected for all patrons

Restricted capacity to 30 people at all casinos, bingo halls, arenas, live theatres, movie theatres, performing arts venues and other facilities that are currently supporting a capacity of 150 people; food and beverage services and activity area must be kept separate
Limited public banquets, conferences, weddings and funeral receptions to 30 people; food and drink must not be present or served
Prohibited indoor gatherings of more than 5 people in private dwellings, including those who regularly live there
Suspended all team/group sports, activities, games, competitions, recitals, practices, etc.
Prohibited places of worship of more than 30 people, including wedding, funeral and baptismal services; food and drink must not be present or served

Expanded mandatory non-medical mask use required during all indoor fitness activities except aquatic activities; all employees and visitors in common areas of businesses and workplaces, and all residents, employees and visitors in all common areas in provincial and municipal correctional facilities must wear a mask
Expanded mandatory non-medical mask use to all students, employees and visitors in all schools; children age 3 to 12 should wear a mask if they are able to
Expanded mandatory non-medical mask use to all employees, children and visitors in daycares; children age 0 to 2 are exempt
Limited customer capacity for large retail locations to 50% or 4 square metres of space per person, whichever is less; enhanced exception of mask use and mitigation measures
Released Saskatchewan COVID-19 Vaccine Delivery Plan with 2 phases

Announced that the first phase of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine delivery will target vaccination of priority population (health care workers, elderly residents in care homes, seniors over 80 years of age and residents over 50 years of age in northern remote communities, and those age 70 to 79 if supply allows)

Prohibited private indoor gatherings, except limiting to household members; single individuals permitted to meet with 1 consistent household of fewer than 5 individuals; co-parenting arrangements, caregivers and support services are permitted; limited outdoor gatherings to 10 people with physical distancing

Updated case definition of infectious period to align with national definition
Discouraged all non-essential interprovincial travel

Issued call for help for health care workers with different backgrounds to assist with the COVID-19 pandemic response and vaccine delivery

Issued directive authorizing Saskatchewan Health Authority staff members whose scope of practice includes the collection of nasopharyngeal throat swabs to perform specimen collection to test for COVID-19 without a physician's order
Updated principles and guidelines for COVID-19 screening at Saskatchewan Health Authority facilities, for both patients and staff

Published updated screening recomendations for health care workers, which emphasize the need for workers to always complete the COVID-19 screening and not minimize symptoms in order to continue working; provided links to supports for those who feel they are unable to miss work due to financial issues, lack of sick days or other reasons despite having COVID-19 symptoms

Announcement of new phase of Temporary Wage Supplement Program targeted to workers in long-term care and home care; will provide $400 a month for two 4-week periods to eligible workers, regardless of income level

Activated next phase of COVID-19 surge plan, which will include redeployment of up to 600 health care workers to strengthen testing and contact tracing, and identifying health care workers necessary for expanding hospital and intensive care unit capacity

Published Daily COVID Readiness Checklist for managers to complete at the start of each work day to ensure health care worker and patient compliance with COVID-19 directives and awareness of current safety measures, such as those surrounding aerosol-generating procedures, personal protective equipment and physical distancing

intervention.who: Government of Yukon, Chief Medical Officer of Health

Strongly advised against non-essential travel in and out of Yukon. Non-Yukon residents must provide valid purpose for entry and disclose the locations they intend to work at and visit.

Keeping park trails, green spaces, water bodies, parking areas and roads within sites, and boat launches open. Campsites, outhouses, shelters, garbage bins, picnic tables and fire pits, among other items listed, are closed.
Civil Emergency Measures Act enforcement officers have been placed at all Yukon borders except with Atlin, B.C.

Increased Yukon border restrictions have been introduced using the new Border Control Measures Order under the Civil Emergency Measures Act. This order details in exactly what situations people can enter Yukon: Yukon residents; non-resident family members of Yukon residents; delivering a critical or essential service; transiting through Yukon to a neighbouring jurisdiction (24-hour limitation); or exercising an Aboriginal or treaty right (for the time needed to exercise the right).
Restricted all non-essential travel and authorized officers to turn individuals away
